case_vignette:
A 14-year-old male with history of leukemia treated with chemotherapy underwent hematopoietic stem cell transplant and on day 30 post therapy was noted to have a rash on the trunk that rapidly spread to the hands, feet, ears. Patient was also reported to have fevers, chills, diarrhea and new transaminitis.  Examination remarkable for acral erythema and scattered pink erythematous macules and poorly demarcated papules on the trunk, extremities with prominent follicular erythema.  The patient was treated with topical corticosteroids and oral antihistamines, but the rash persisted.  The patient was then treated with oral corticosteroids and the rash resolved.  The patient was also treated with antibiotics for the fevers and chills.  The patient was diagnosed with graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) and the rash was a manifestation of GVHD.

I have a rash on my trunk that has spread to my hands, feet, and ears, and I'm also experiencing fevers, chills, and diarrhea.
